keyTakeAways: Americans show little enthusiasm for President Donald Trump’s handling of the Gaza ceasefire deal, despite its global recognition as a significant diplomatic achievement.
Trump’s approval ratings remain at or near a low point, with 61% disapproving of his overall performance—his worst numbers since 2017.
A 47% approval rating on Gaza (with 49% disapproval) suggests a narrow and unstable public response to the deal, indicating lack of confidence in its long-term success.
Trump’s economic approval ratings are worse than on any previous occasion in either term, with 62% disapproving of his handling of inflation and the cost of living.
Americans are increasingly pessimistic about the economy—only 32% expect economic improvement in the next year and 31% expect wage growth.
Employed Americans are increasingly concerned about job security, with only 52% saying they are not worried about losing their jobs.
Public priority on foreign policy is low—only 4% of Americans consider international events the top national issue.
A significant portion of Americans believe Trump has failed to prioritize lowering prices, indicating that domestic economic concerns outweigh foreign policy successes.

summaryOfNewsArticle: Despite the global attention and perceived success of a recent Gaza ceasefire deal brokered by President Donald Trump, domestic public opinion has remained largely unimpressed. Polls from AP-NORC and CNBC show that while Trump's approval on the Gaza issue slightly improved, his overall approval rating has dropped to a near-term low, with strong disapproval on economic issues such as inflation, rising costs, and job insecurity. Americans express deep skepticism about the deal’s durability, reflecting broader fatigue with foreign policy successes. Meanwhile, economic pessimism is on the rise, with declining expectations for wage growth and economic recovery, and a majority of Americans believe Trump has not prioritized lowering prices. These findings suggest that, in the eyes of the public, domestic economic issues—especially inflation and job stability—outweigh foreign policy achievements, reinforcing the idea that 'it’s the economy, stupid' remains a dominant political narrative.
title: Americans shrug at Trump’s Gaza deal, as economic fears reign
